introduction.p: Here's a strong opening statement: everyone working in mathematics should have a CoCalc account. Even if you don't need access to most of the strong features installed in the CoCalc environment, there's an excellent editor for working with , which is the typesetting language of professional mathematics. Moreover the editor allows for seamless collaboration... that's what CoCalc means: Collaborative Calculation. For anyone who wants to work computationally and does not want to bear the cost of expensive commercial mathematics software, here's a partial list of what is installed in CoCalc:

ul.li: Many major programming languages via gcc.

introduction.p: If this sounds like an advertisement, it is! All drafts of this text after the first were authored in CoCalc, since the editor handles XML remarkably well.

subsubsection.title: The CoCalc User Manual
subsubsection.p: For a high-level overview of what is possible with CoCalc, see the CoCalc User Manual; specifically there is a section for students called the Student Guide.

subsubsection.title: Paid CoCalc accounts
subsubsection.p: Paying for CoCalc entitles you to a certain number of upgrades which can be allocated on a project-by-project basis. The most important of these is member hosting, which makes your project run on a more stable server in the Google cloud. It is highly recommended that any project that is important to you runs in a member-hosted project, which means that CoCalc ceases to be a free service. There is a short-term subscription option for students.

subsection.title: Assignments and handouts
subsection.p: If you are using this textbook for a course and if your instructor has adopted CoCalc's course functionality, you may receive assignments directly into the project associated with your course. All the work you do in the folder which corresponds to an assignment will be collected by the instructor; there is no way to submit work.
Handouts are distributed via a similar mechanism. They will appear in your project whenever your instructor publishes them to you.

subsection.title: Collaboration
subsection.p: The name of CoCalc is an abbreviation for Collaborative Calculation. As such, project owners can add other CoCalc users as collaborators on any project. However, this is project-level collaboration. You cannot share a single file or collaborate on a single file. Also, collaborators have full read/write privilege in the project.
subsection.warning: Only add CoCalc collaborators you actually trust!
